title: Ancient Chinese Treatment Could Be Effective in Treating Spinal Cord Injuries - Science World
author: Rick Pantaleo

cleaned_text: have been used to treat a variety of ailments for centuries. Now [a new study](http://iospress.metapress.com/content/k2107l8l26664548/) finds an ancient medicinal practice, called Ji-Sui-Kang (JSK), can improve [locomotor function](http://neurolex.org/wiki/Category:Locomotor_function) in rats with [spinal cord injuries](http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/spinalcordinjuries.html). The researchers reported that after being treated with JSK, the injured rats showed decreased tissue damage and the structure of their [neural cells](http://www.wisegeek.com/what-are-the-different-types-of-neural-cell.htm) was better preserved when compared to rats in a [control group](http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/control+group). The data also showed that JSK treatment might reduce [inflammation](http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/248423.php) and [cell death](http://www.thefreedictionary.com/cell+death), as well as boost local oxygen supply in the affected area. After a while, the JSK appeared to restore function and promote [tissue regeneration](http://www.utwente.nl/mira/research/tissue_regeneration/). Those involved with the study say their work provides an important foundation for further study into the use of JSK therapy. "A number of anecdotal reports from Chinese medicine practitioners indicate that treatment with a novel herbal formulation, JSK, for periods of one week or three months improved functional recovery," said the study's co-lead investigator Shucui Jiang, head of the [Hamilton NeuroRestorative Group](http://www.neurorestorativegroup.com/) at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. For this study, the researchers divided their rat test subjects into two groups. One group was treated with the herbal medicine treatment while the control group was given a [saline solution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saline_%28medicine%29). Treatment began immediately after spinal cord injury and the test period was 21 days. The investigators reported that, within seven days of the start of their experiment, the hind limb locomotor function was significantly better in the group of rats treated with JSK as compared to the group that only got the saline. Throughout the 21-day test period, the rats treated with JSK continued to display better [motor function](http://psychologydictionary.org/motor-function/), appeared to support their weight better, and showed more coordinated movement than those in the control group. After examining microscopic samples of the spinal cord from rats in each group, the researchers found that the structure of the injured spinal cord of those treated with JSK was better preserved. Additionally, the size of the injured area was significantly reduced about a week after the injury. "Our data suggest that JSK may enhance tissue recovery by reducing cell growth inhibitors and by promoting the proliferation of cells within the injured spinal cord," said the other co-lead investigator Michel Rathbone, a professor at the [Department of Medicine at McMaster University](http://fhs.mcmaster.ca/medicine/). The researchers said their study suggests JSK treatment could help protect against further spinal cord injury caused by damage to local blood vessels. Citing proprietary reasons, the authors of the study did not reveal the entire herbal composition of their JSK treatment.
